citation.article-title: Description of two new species of Halomonas: Halomonas israelensis sp.nov. and Halomonas canadensis sp.nov.

p.s: Description of Halomonas israelensis sp. nov.
Halomonas israelensis (iz.ra.len.sis; an inhabitant of Israel)
Halomonas israelensis (ATCC 43985T) appears as straight Gram-negative rods with rounded ends and divides by transverse fission.
Single cells predominate. occasionally producing paired cells and short chains.
Colonies growing at 3O°C on complex CAS medium with 8% w/v NaCl are 2-6 mm wide in 7 days with entire margins.
Colonies are flat with nondiffusible cream pigment and grow aerobically from pH 5.0 to 9.0 in CAS medium with 8% NaCl.
Optimal growth occurs when NaCl concentration is 8.0% w/v and the growth temperature is 3O°C.
Colonies grow in media with 3.5-20% NaCl from 15 to 45°C, without added NaCl from 15 to 30°C and in 32% w/v NaCl from 30 to 45°C.
Halomonas israelensis requires Na+ ions for growth.
It is catalase positive, oxidase negative, lysine decarboxylase and ornithine decarboxylase positive, and phenylalanine deaminase negative.

It grows in elevated CO2 (candle jar) on complex medium with 8% NaCl, reduces NO3 to NO2. produces indole. grows only at the surface of thioglycollate-containing 8% NaCl, and is urease and methyl red negative.
H2S (TSI, SIM) and acetyl methyl carbinol are not produced.
Colonies are insensitive to valinomycin, monensin, aphidicolin, penicillin G, ampicillin. and streptomycin when tested at 8% NaCl.

This species utilizes mannose, aesculin, cellobiose, lactose, glycerol, starch, gluconic acid, and sucrose as its sole carbon sources in chemically defined medium with 8% w/v NaCl It produces acid, but no gas, from mannose, lactose, glycerol, and sucrose.
The G+C content of this species is 64 mol% by bouyant density.
The DNA shows 49% homology to H. elongala ATCC 33173T and 20% homology to H. canadensis NRCC 41227T.
DNA homology was determined by the dot blot method. Halomonas isradensis was isolated in 1968 from the Dead Sea by Rafaeli-Eshkol (1968).
The type strain of this species is ATCC 43985.
